questions.text: Which of the following does not supply the palate?
questions.solution:
The tonsillar branch of facial artery supplies the palatine tonsil and not the palate.

Blood supply of the palate:

  • Hard palate - greater (descending) palatine artery which is a branch of the third part of the maxillary artery.
  • Soft palate - ascending palatine branch of the facial artery, ascending pharyngeal artery, and lesser palatine arteries.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not pierced during a lumbar puncture?
questions.solution:
The posterior longitudinal ligament is not pierced during lumbar puncture.

Structures pierced during lumbar puncture (in that order):

  • Skin
  • Subcutaneous tissue
  • Supraspinous ligament
  • Interspinous ligament
  • Ligamentum flavum
  • Epidural space
  • Dura mater
  • Arachnoid mater
  • Subarachnoid space

Mnemonic: 3S I LED AS

questions.text: After overnight fasting, levels of glucose transporters are reduced in ___________.
questions.solution:
Levels of insulin-sensitive receptor GLUT-4 decreases after overnight fasting. The passive uptake of glucose by muscle and adipose tissue is catalyzed by the GLUT-4 transporter.

In the absence of insulin, most GLUT 4 molecules are sequestered in membrane vesicles within the cell, but when blood glucose rises, the release of insulin triggers GLUT 4 movement to the plasma membrane.

questions.text: A pregnant couple presented to the OPD with concerns about thalassemia in their baby due to a positive family history. Genetic studies revealed that both she and her husband are carriers. What is the probability that the child will have thalassemia major?
questions.solution:
There is 25% probability that their child will have thalassemia major.

β-thalassemia occurs due to mutations causing an impaired synthesis of β-globin chains of hemoglobin (Hb), leading to anemia, hypoxia, and hemolysis. The mutations can be of two types:

  1. Absent β chain synthesis (β0)
  2. Reduced β chain synthesis (β+)

Being an autosomal recessive disease, disease occurs only when both alleles are defective. When only one is defective, they are called carriers or trait. Here as both the parents are carriers, their alleles will be β/β0 or β/β+ (1 β-thalassemia allele and 1 normal allele). As the clinical disease doesn't alter much based on it being β+ or β0, its safe to use use β+ to represent a thalassemia allele.

  β β+ 
β β/β β/β+
β+ β/β+ β+/β+

Thalassemia major means both alleles are mutated. And from the table, that can occur in one of the four ways possible. Hence the answer is 25%

 Clinical syndromes of β-thalassemia depending on the genetic defect:

Major: 

  • Severe microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells, basophilic stippling, and fragmented red cells (typical Hb: 3 to 6 g/dL), requiring regular blood transfusions
  • Crewcut appearance of facial bones and skull (due to cortical bone erosion by expanding marrow and new bone formation)
  • Speen, liver, and lymph node enlargement (due to extramedullary hematopoiesis)

Minor: 

  • More common
  • Usually asymptomatic
  • Mild microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells and basophilic stippling (important to rule out iron deficiency anemia by serum iron studies)
  • Mild erythroid hyperplasia in bone marrow

Other features:

  Major Minor (also called trait)
Genotype

β0/β0, β0/β+, β+/β+ (2 β-thalassemia alleles)

β/β0 or β/β+ (1 β-thalassemia allele and 1 normal allele)
Hb
electro-phoresis

HbF: Major Hb, markedly elevated

HbA2: Usually normal to low

HbA: Absent or present in small amounts

HbA2: Increased (4-8%) with an elevated ratio of δ-chain to β-chain synthesis

HbF: Normal or slightly increased

A third clinical syndrome of moderate severity is called β-thalassemia intermedia. The genotype in this type includes milder variants of β+/β+ or β0/β+ and does not require regular transfusions.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with nausea, vomiting, and four episodes of loose stools. On history taking, he reveals to have consumed food from a restaurant 3 hours back. Which of the following is wrong about the toxin involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of an acute episode of food poisoning caused by Staphylococcus aureus. The toxin involved, enterotoxins, are heat stable.

Staphylococcus causes nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea 2-6 hours after consuming contaminated food (other organisms causing food poisoning within the same time period of 2-6 hours is Bacillus cereus-Emetic strains).

Enterotoxin produced by Staphylococcus:

  • There are 15 enterotoxins, they are superantigens
  • It is a preformed toxin that is heat stable (Most of the other exotoxins are heat-labile).
  • Site of action: This toxin stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting centre of the brain and also stimulates the intestinal peristaltic activity.

questions.text: A patient presents with urinary symptoms due to benign prostatic hyperplasia. Which of the following is used to manage the urinary symptoms in the initial stage of this condition?
questions.solution:
Tamsulosin is used for the management of urinary symptoms in the initial stages of Benign prostatic hyperplasia(BPH). It improves the urinary flow by inhibiting the smooth muscle contraction of the prostate thereby reducing the resistance at the bladder neck.

BPH is characterized by symptoms of urinary frequency, urgency, nocturia, incontinence, slow urinary stream, straining to void, urinary intermittency (stream starting and stopping during micturition), or hesitancy, splitting of the voiding stream, and terminal dribbling. Physical examination reveals a smooth enlarged and non-tender prostate. Lab investigations reveal a normal PSA (prostate-specific antigen). Diagnosis is made based on clinical presentation and a lack of lab findings suggestive of malignancy (elevated PSA). A biopsy is rarely indicated.

Conservative treatment is recommended for men with mild symptoms, flow rate >10ml/s, and good bladder emptying with residual urine <100ml. 

Medical management includes alpha-adrenergic blocking agents that inhibit the contraction of smooth muscle that is found in the prostate. Tamsulosin is an adrenoreceptor antagonist with receptor selectivity at α1A. It is used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia.

The other class of drugs is the 5α-reductase inhibitors, which inhibit the conversion of testosterone to DHT, the most active form of androgen. Finasteride is a 5α-reductase enzyme inhibitor. It is effective in the treatment of palpable enlarged prostate. These drugs result in a 25% shrinkage of the prostate gland.

Indications for surgical management:

  • Lower urinary tract symptoms that are refractory to medical therapy
  • Refractory urinary retention
  • Recurrent urinary tract infection (UTI)
  • Hematuria
  • Stone formation
  • Hydronephrosis, hydroureter with renal functional impairment

Surgical management involves the use of the transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP). Laser ablative techniques using holmium YAG can also be done. 

Other options:

  • Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic medication that can help relax smooth muscles in certain parts of the body, but it is not specifically indicated for treating BPH-related symptoms. 

  • Finasteride: Finasteride belongs to a class of drugs known as 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors. It is used in the treatment of BPH to reduce the size of the prostate gland over time, but it may take several months of treatment for noticeable effects to occur.

  • Danazol: Danazol is primarily known for its use in treating endometriosis and certain other conditions, including hereditary angioedema. Danazol is not considered a first-line or typical therapy for BPH.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with a ​history of perianal pain is brought to the OPD. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, it produces yellow rhombic crystals of spermine picrate. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
The test done in the scenario is Barberio test. It is used to detect seminal fluid.

When saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the spermatic fluid, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are produced.

Other options: 

Option B: Florence test: 

  • The suspected seminal stain is extracted with 10% hydrochloric acid and a drop of it is placed over a slide.
  • A coverslip is placed over it and a drop of Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water) is made to run under the coverslip.
  • If semen is present, dark brown rhombic or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide appear immediately.

Option C: Takayama test (Hemochromogen crystal test): 

  • The test is used to detect suspected bloodstains. Small piece of suspected material is added on a glass slide.
  • Then, 2-3 drops of Takayama reagent is added and covered with a coverslip.
  • If it is a bloodstain, pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen or reduced alkaline hematin appear in a few minutes.

Option D: Teichmann test (Hemin Crystal Test): 

  • The test is used to detect suspected bloodstains.
  • Small piece of suspected material is placed on a glass slide. Then, 2-3 drops of glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride are added to the glass slide and covered with a coverslip. The slide is then heated.
  • If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish-red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of hemin or hematin chloride appear.
  • When hydrogen peroxide is added, the hematin crystals give bubbles of gas.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male patient presented with a nasal mass and intermittent epistaxis. On examination, the mass is reaching up to the cheek and causing a unilateral obstruction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient, with these clinical features, most likely has an angiofibroma. 

Angiofibroma, a benign tumor that affects young male patients, is the most common benign tumor of the nasopharynx. It is a histologically benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor that grows at the back of the nasal cavity.

  • Origin: It originates from the fibrovascular stroma on the posterolateral wall of the nasal cavity in the area of the sphenopalatine foramen.

A vascular tumor arising from the periosteum with fibrous tissue and blood vessels.

It encroaches by expanding into surrounding areas like the nasal cavity, sphenoidal sinus, pterygopalatine fossa, maxillary sinus, orbit, and cranial cavity.

Clinical Features

    • Blocking of the nose
    • Epistaxis
    • Secondary sexual characters not well developed
    • Rhinolalia clausa
    • Anterior/ posterior rhinoscopy
    • Bulging of soft palate +/-
    • Spread by expansion

Biopsy should not be attempted

Blood supply is most commonly from the internal maxillary artery of that side.

Treatment:

  • Wilson’s transpalatal approach
  • Lateral rhinotomy
  • If intracranial extension
  • Role is doubtful
    • Excision
    • Radiation
    • Hormonal therapy

questions.text: A patient who presents to the OPD has a visual field defect as shown below. What is the probable site of the lesion based on the image displayed?
questions.solution:
The visual field defect in the image is indicative of bitemporal hemianopia, so the probable site of the lesion is the optic chiasma marked as 3 in the image given. 

Options marked in the image are:

1. Left optic nerve 
3. Otic chiasma
4. Left optic tract 
5. Left lateral geniculate nucleus

Hemianopia or hemianopsia refers to loss of sight in half the visual field. Bitemporal hemianopia refers to loss of sight in the temporal halves of the visual field, seen in lesions affecting the optic chiasma. The most common cause of this is pituitary gland tumours. Other causes include suprasellar aneurysms, chronic arachnoiditis, and suprasellar tumours like craniopharyngioma and suprasellar meningioma.

Damage to the middle part of the optic chiasm affects fibres crossing at the nasal retina of each eye, leaving the uncrossed fibres from the temporal retinas intact. The resulting loss of vision is confined to the temporal visual field of each eye and this is known as bitemporal hemianopia. It is also called heteronymous hemianopia to emphasize the fact that the parts of the visual field that are lost in each eye do not overlap.

Individuals with this condition are able to see in both left and right central visual fields, with both eyes open. However, all information from the most peripheral parts of visual fields (which are seen only by the nasal retinas) is lost.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: The cornerstone of treatment for a patient of dengue with warning signs is:
questions.solution:
The mainstay of treatment for a patient of dengue with warning signs is IV fluids.

The main pathology in dengue is plasma leakage resulting in intravascular volume depletion and thereby shock. So, supportive management with continuous infusion of crystalloid IV fluids remains the primary modality of treatment in these patients. And often patients respond well to supportive management.

Platelet transfusion is limited to patients with severe thrombocytopenia (<10,000/mm3) and active bleeding.

FFP and cryoglobulins are not the preferred treatment modality in dengue.

Warning signs in dengue include 

  • Abdominal pain or tenderness
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Clinical fluid accumulation (ascites, pleural effusion)
  • Mucosal bleeding
  • Lethargy or restlessness
  • Hepatomegaly >2 cm
  • Increase in hematocrit concurrent with a rapid decrease in platelet count

Inpatient management is advised for all patients with dengue with warning signs.

questions.text: The process in the oxidation pond is ________________

choices.text: Aerobic during day, anaerobic during night
Anaerobic during day, aerobic during night

questions.solution:
The process in the oxidation ponds is aerobic during day, and anaerobic during night.

An oxidation pond is a method of sewage disposal that is used to treat both sewage and industrial waste. It is an open, shallow pool of around 1 – 1.5m depth with an inlet and outlet. It requires algae, certain types of saprophytic bacteria and sunlight.

The organic matter is oxidized by bacteria into carbon dioxide, ammonia and water. Algae grow by utilising these with the help of sunlight creating a balance. The oxidation ponds are predominantly aerobic during sunshine hours and some hours of the night. In the remaining hours of the night, the bottom layers are generally anaerobic. The effluent formed can be used for land irrigation or can be forwarded for further treatment.

questions.text: A  woman presents with sudden onset of fever, altered mental status, confusion, and petechiae over both lower limbs. Laboratory reports were suggestive of acute kidney injury. Peripheral smear showed thrombocytopenia and schistocytes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is thrombotic microangiopathy. It results from antibodies to metalloprotease ADAMTS13, which normally cleaves multimers of vWF. Failure to cleave these multimers results in excessive platelet adhesion and aggregation. This leads to platelet thrombi and fibrin deposits at various sites. These thrombi result in the classic pentad of: 

  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Renal failure
  • Neurologic findings
  • Fever

The platelet thrombi narrow the vessel lumen, causing shearing stress on the red blood cells that are passing through. This results in microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. On peripheral smear, these fragmented red cells appear as schistocytes or helmet cells, as shown in the image below:

They are treated using plasma exchange therapy. Glucocorticoids can also be used along with this therapy. In refractory cases, rituximab, vincristine, cyclophosphamide, and even splenectomy can be tried. 

Other causes of microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia include:

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) (Most common)
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)

Other options-

Option (A): Immune thrombocytopenic purpura occurs as a chronic disease in adults with several episodes over time, usually following infections. It presents with mucocutaneous bleeding and very low platelet counts. These patients have otherwise normal peripheral blood pictures.

Option (B): Disseminated intravascular coagulation refers to the widespread intravascular clot formation, commonly due to sepsis, trauma, and obstetric complications. These patients present with petechiae, ecchymoses, oozing from venipuncture sites, etc. They do not display the classic pentad seen in TTP. Schistocytes may be present on peripheral smear. Deranged clotting parameters are seen only in DIC and not in TTP.

Option (C): Hemolytic uremic syndrome is a disorder seen predominantly in children, following an episode of bloody diarrhea. Escherichia coli O157:H7 is most commonly the cause of this diarrhea. It can also present with acute renal failure, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia, but neurological manifestations are less common. ADAMTS13 levels are normal in a majority of patients. It can be low in some rare cases.

questions.text: Identify the deformity depicted in the image.
questions.solution:
The image shows flexion of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint with hyperextension of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. This deformity is known as Boutonnière deformity seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

 Rheumatoid Arthritis :

It is a chronic inflammatory disease. Its incidence increases between 25 and 55 years of age.

Signs and symptoms -

  • Swelling and pain of the small joints of the hands initially(spares DIP joint)
  • Morning stiffness
  • Swan-neck deformity(hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint), Boutonnière deformity(flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint), or Z-line deformity(subluxation of the first MCP joint with hyperextension of the first interphalangeal (IP) joint )
  • Ulnar deviation of fingers
  • Constitutional findings such as fever, weight loss, etc
  • Monoarthritis of large joints can occur later
  • Tenosynovitis of palm(trigger finger0
  • Atlantoaxial joint involvement

Joints commonly affected in Rheumatoid Arthritis: (bilateral and symmetrically involved) 

  • MCP joints
  • Wrists
  • PIP joints
  • MTP joints
  • Atlantoaxial joint

Diagnosis is made with clinical signs and symptoms with corroboration from lab and imaging findings.

Anti-CCP, RF, and synovial fluid analysis are important lab investigations.

X-ray findings show -
soft tissue swelling, joint space narrowing, periarticular osteopenia, and bony erosions

Treatment of rheumatoid arthritis (RA)

DMARDs (Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs) are the mainstay of treatment.

Methotrexate is the drug of choice in patients with RA. It can be used alone (in low disease activity) or with a 3-drug combination (in high disease activity) with other DMARDs such as hydroxychloroquine, sulfasalazine, and leflunomide (reserve drug).

  • It is a folic acid analong
  • Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase
  • Causes reversible myelosuppression
  • Leucovorin is used to manage myelosuppression
  • Can cause pulmonary fibrosis
  • Escalation with triple therapy involves - methotrexate + sulfasalazine + hydroxychloroquine
  • Glucocorticoids 

Other extra-articular manifestations are:

  • Sjogren's syndrome
  • Pericarditis, Mitral regurgitation
  • Pleuritis, Interstitial Lung disease
  • Vasculitis
  • Felty's syndrome
  • Diffuse large B cell lymphoma

The image below shows extraarticular manifestations of rheumatoid arthritis -

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Subluxation of the 1st MCP joint with hyperextension of the 1st IP joint. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with the finding shown in the given image. Which among the following conditions is least likely to cause this presentation?
questions.solution:
The given image shows digital clubbing. Among the given options, aortic dissection is least likely to cause digital clubbing.

Clubbing is a selective bulbous enlargement of the distal segments of the fingers and toes due to the proliferation of connective tissue, particularly on the dorsal surface.

Clubbing can occur secondary to:

  • Pulmonary disease: Lung cancer, bronchiectasis, asbestosis, sarcoidosis, lung abscess, cystic fibrosis, tuberculosis, and mesothelioma
  • Cardiac disease: Cyanotic congenital heart disease, other causes of right-to-left shunting, and bacterial endocarditis.
  • Gastrointestinal disease: Ulcerative colitis, Crohn disease, primary biliary cirrhosis, cirrhosis of the liver.
  • Skin disease: Palmoplantar keratoderma, and Fischer-Volavsek syndrome.
  • Malignancies: Thyroid cancer, thymus cancer, Hodgkin disease, and disseminated chronic myeloid leukemia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was admitted to the hospital with difficulty in breathing. He had puffiness around the eyes, pitting edema of the lower limbs, and ascites. His 24-hour urine protein shows a protein level of 4 g/24h. CT chest shows a saddle embolus. What is the cause of this patient's CT findings?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of a diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome complicated to pulmonary embolism. Thrombo-embolic complications in nephrotic syndrome are due to the loss of endogenous anticoagulants such as antithrombin III in the urine.

Nephrotic syndrome is a condition that occurs due to damage in the glomerular capillary walls thereby leading to increased capillary permeability to plasma proteins.

The manifestations and the mechanisms of nephrotic syndrome are:

  • Massive proteinuria (>3.5 grams) as a result of leakage in the barrier formed by glomerular basement membrane, endothelium, and visceral epithelial cells.
  • Hypoalbuminemia (albumin <3g/dL) occurs as a consequence of proteinuria. Also, increased catabolism of the kidney contributes to hypoalbuminemia. 
  • Generalized edema is seen. The edema is soft and pitting seen in periorbital and dependent portions of the body. It occurs as a result of decreased intravascular colloid osmotic pressure and other factors like sodium and water retention lead to edema. 
  • Hyperlipidemia occurs following the increased synthesis of lipoproteins, lipid particles, and decreased catabolism of lipids.
  • Lipiduria is due to leakage of lipids through the glomerular capillary wall.

Increased susceptibility to infections is another complication. It is due to loss of immunoglobulins in the urine.

The image shows the pathophysiology of nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text: An elderly female was brought to the hospital with a history of severe pain in the renal angle for the past 7 hours. Ultrasound of the kidney reveals a renal stone of 2.5 cm. What is the treatment of choice in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for renal calculi of size 2.5 cm is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL).

PCNL is the treatment of choice for large renal stones of diameter more than 2cm. PCNL is indicated in the following types of renal calculi:

  • Staghorn calculi
  • Multiple stones
  • Proximal ureteral stone: >1 cm

Technique: Endoscopic instruments are passed into the kidney using a percutaneous technique and stones are removed.

questions.text: An infant who is diagnosed with congenital hypothyroidism presents with the following hernia. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of this child?

choices.text: The hernia may spontaneously resolve by 2 years of age
Surgical repair is indicated if the hernia persists for more than 5 years of age
Strangulation is a common complication associated with this type of hernia
Mayo’s procedure or mesh repair can be done for this hernia

questions.solution:
The given clinical history of congenital hypothyroidism and the image showing a mass protruding out of the umbilicus is indicative of an umbilical hernia. Obstruction and strangulation are uncommon below the age of 3 years.

Congenital hypothyroidism is a condition caused by an embryological defect in the thyroid gland or thyroid hormone synthesis.

Congenital hypothyroidism is commonly associated with other features such as:

  • Myxedematous facies
  • Large fontanelles
  • Macroglossia
  • Umbilical hernia
  • Hypotonia

Mayo’s operation is done for an umbilical hernia. Indications for surgery in umbilical hernia are:

  • Defect size >2cm
  • Persisting beyond 5 years
  • Progressively enlarging after 2 years of age (usually regresses spontaneously by 2 years of age)
  • Symptomatic
  • Strangulated

questions.text: Following a road traffic accident, a child presents with abdominal pain. On examination, vitals are stable and tenderness is present in the left lumbar region. What is the investigation of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with abdominal pain and tenderness in the left lumbar region following a road traffic accident is suggestive of blunt renal trauma. The investigation of choice is contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) in a hemodynamically stable patient.

Blunt trauma is the main cause of renal injuries and is self-limiting. Radiological investigations are indicated when there is gross hematuria, shock in combination with microscopic hematuria, pediatric renal trauma, and penetrating injuries.

CECT is the investigation of choice. It assesses the extent of the injury, showing laceration, extravasation, surrounding hemorrhage, and vessel injury. It also shows non-renal injuries and effectively stages renal pedicle injuries. Arterial occlusion will manifest as rim enhancement of the normal renal contour.

Blunt trauma is mostly treated conservatively. Most penetrating injuries require surgical renal exploration.

Absolute indications for surgical intervention in renal trauma are

  • Massive hemorrhage
  • Renal pedicle avulsion (grade 5 injury)
  • Expanding, pulsatile, or uncontained retroperitoneal hematoma

Relative indications are

  • Large laceration of the renal pelvis or avulsion of the ureteropelvic junction
  • Bowel or pancreatic injuries
  • Persistent urinary leakage, postinjury urinoma, or perinephric abscess 
  • Complete renal artery thrombosis of both kidneys 
  • Renal hypertension

Exploratory laparotomy is recommended in stable patients with penetrating renal injuries.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) kidney Injury Scale

questions.text: A 46-year old lady is being evaluated for abnormal uterine bleeding by a dilatation and curettage procedure. The following instruments are placed on a table in the minor operating theatre. Which of the following instruments will be used in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Among the given instruments 1, 2, and 3 - Sim's uterine curette, Hegar's dilators, and Simpson's uterine sound are used for dilatation and curettage (D&C).

Instruments used in D&C:

  • Sim’s speculum: It retracts the posterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix
  • Anterior vaginal wall retractor: Retracts the anterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix.
  • Vulsellum or Allis forceps: To hold the anterior lip of the cervix
  • Uterine sound: Simpson's uterine sound is a 30 cm long angulated instrument with a handle at one end and a rounded blunt tip at the other.
    It is used to measure the length of the uterus. It can be identified by the markings used for measurement
  • Cervical dilators: 
    • Hegar's dilator is a double-ended dilator used to dilate the cervix.
    • Hawkins’ single-ended dilator 
    • Fenton’s dilator
  • Curette:
    • Sim's curette is a single-ended curette
    • Blake's curette is a double-ended curette

Other options: 

Karman's cannula: It is used for menstrual regulation. 

Leech Wilkinson's cannula and Rubin's cannula are used in hysterosalpingography.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: You are performing a cardiotocograph on a woman in labor, and your findings are shown below. What could be the possible cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
The given cardiotocograph shows decelerations that are variable with respect to the size, shape, depth, duration, and timing of uterine contractions. This is indicative of variable decelerations, and the likely cause among the given options is umbilical cord compression

Baseline variability is observed in many conditions such as:

1. Acceleration: Transient increase in fetal heart rate (FHR) by 15 bpm or more, lasting for at least 15 seconds. It denotes intact neurohormonal and cardiovascular activity and, therefore, a healthy fetus.

2. Deceleration: Transient decrease in FHR below the baseline by 15 bpm or more and lasting ≥15 seconds. Three basic types of deceleration are early, late, and variable:

  • Early deceleration/ Type I Dips: Slowing of FHR and in most cases, the phases of the deceleration (onset, nadir, and recovery) coincide with those of the uterine contraction (beginning, peak, and ending). It is due to head compression (vagal nerve activation).

 

  • Late deceleration/ Type II Dips: that begins after the onset of the uterine contraction. Usually, the onset, nadir and recovery of the deceleration occur after the start, peak and end of the uterine contraction respectively. It suggests uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia (50%). Causes of late deceleration: (i) Placental pathology (postmaturity, hypertension, diabetes, placental abruption); (ii) Excessive uterine contractions; (iii) Injudicious use of oxytocin; (iv) Regional anaesthesia (spinal or epidural)

 

  • Variable deceleration: The most common type of deceleration. Here the decelerations are variable, with varying parameters of size, shape, depth, duration, and timing with respect to uterine contractions. They indicate cord compression and may disappear when the patient's position is altered. Accelerations often precede and follow this type of deceleration.

 

3. Prolonged deceleration is the abrupt decrease in FHR to levels below the baseline, and it lasts for >3 min but <10 min. If it lasts for >10 min, it is a baseline change.

4. Lag period: It is the time taken for the FHR to reach the nadir (the lowest point of the FHR dip) from the apex of the preceding uterine contraction. In deceleration, the lag period is >30 seconds.

5. Sinusoidal pattern: It resembles a sine wave. It has a stable baseline FHR with fixed or absent baseline variability lasting >20 min. Accelerations are absent. It is often associated with fetal anaemia and fetomaternal haemorrhage. It may occur when narcotics are given to the mother. Such FHR patterns are called pseudo-sinusoidal as the fetus is well-oxygenated.

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman at 36 weeks gestation comes with a history of multiple episodes of convulsions at home. The diagnosis of eclampsia is made. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The next step in the management of eclampsia is the administration of MgSO4 + Intravenous labetalol.

The first step in the management of eclampsia is maintaining the airway and preventing aspiration.

The immediate measures in the medical management of eclampsia include the following steps:

  • Call for extra help (Communication)
  • To put the patient in a left lateral recumbent position and maintain oral airway
  • O2 inhalation 
  • Secure IV lines: 1 or 2 wide bore cannulas and start fluids.
  • Catheterize the patient with a Foley's catheter and an urometer
  • Control of seizures: MgSO4 (IV/IM regimens)
  • Control of hypertension: Labetalol
  • Oropharyngeal suction
  • Diuretics administration for pulmonary edema, if present.

The definitive management of eclampsia is always the termination of pregnancy irrespective of gestational age. If labor does not start and the seizures are controlled, a mature baby is vaginally delivered by induction of labor. If the baby is premature, steroids are given(<34 weeks) and delivery is conducted. In case of obstetric contraindications for a vaginal delivery, a cesarean section should be done to deliver the fetus.

Intravenous labetalol is the first-line agent for control of BP in pregnancy. It is a nonselective β blocker and vascular α blocker It has a rapid onset of action. It should be avoided in patients with asthma and congestive heart failure due to bronchoconstriction.

MgSO4 is used for the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe pre-eclampsia. Magnesium is mainly used in preeclampsia due to its specific anticonvulsant action and neuroprotective action on the cortex. MgSO4 acts as a membrane stabilizer. It reduces motor endplate sensitivity to acetylcholine and blocks neuronal calcium influx. It is not used to treat hypertension, although it shows some hypotensive action by decreasing vascular response to vasopressors.

The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4-7mEq/L. The two regimens commonly used are Pritchard and Sibai regimen.

Regimen    Loading Dose    Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard)  4g (20% solution) IV over 3-5 minute
 followed by 10g (5O%), deep IM
 (5 gm in each buttock)		  5g (5O%) IM 4 hourly in the   alternate buttocks
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai)  4g IV slow over 15-20 minute  1-2g/h IV infusion

questions.text: A mother has brought her 6-month-old infant to a pediatrician for a regular checkup. She tells her baby's weight was approximately double the birth weight at 5 months of age. The baby's weight would be approximately triple the birth weight by the age of:
questions.solution:
The baby's weight would be approximately triple the birth weight by the age of 1 year.  

Infant weight approximately doubles by the age of 5 months, triples by 1 year, and is 4 times by 2 years of age. Infants may lose up to 10% of their birth weight in the 1st week of life as a result of excretion of excess extravascular fluid and limited nutritional intake. They regain their birth weight by their 2nd week and thereafter gain weight at specific rates at specific age groups.

The growth and development of a child between the age of 6-12 months can be classified as:

  • Physical Development:  By 12 months of age, birth weight has tripled, length has increased by 50%, and head circumference has increased by 10 cm. A mature pincer grasp occurs and tooth eruption has started to occur. Motor achievements correlate with increasing myelinization and cerebellar growth.
  • Cognitive Development: Object permanence appears by 9 months of age. The baby tries to search for a hidden object.
  • Emotional Development: Infants may cling or cry anxiously when a stranger approaches, demonstrating stranger anxiety. Separation anxiety can also seen.
  • Linguistic Development: Between 8 and 10 months of age, infants produce multisyllabic sounds (“ba-da-ma”) called canonical babbling. Babies can discriminate between languages.

Related Pearl: Weight and height changes in children

Term newborns may lose up to 10% of their birth weight in the first few days of life (due to extracellular fluid losses). Most healthy newborns typically regain their birth weight by 10 to 14 days. Thereafter, approximate daily weight gain is as follows :

  • 0-3 months ~ 30 grams/day
  • 3-6 months ~ 20 grams/day
  • 6-12months ~ 12-15 grams/day

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presents with painful swelling in the middle finger around the proximal phalanx. An X-ray was done and it is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette and X-ray findings point toward the diagnosis of enchondroma.

Enchondromas are benign tumors consisting of a lobulated mass of cartilage encapsulated by fibrous tissue. It is more commonly seen in 20 to 30 years of age. Small bones of hands and feet are commonly involved followed by the femur and humerus. 

The patient usually presents with long-standing swelling from one or more phalanges or metacarpals, without much pain. Diagnosis can be done by X-ray, which can show expanding lytic lesions, occasionally, a biopsy will be required if the diagnosis is unclear. Enchondromas of long bones may undergo malignant transformation into chondrosarcoma.

Treatment is removal by curettage and it is indicated if there is pain or pathological fracture.

Other options:

Option A: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignancy of bone that produces osteoid matrix or mineralized bone.  X-ray shows periosteal reaction and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance as shown below.

Option B: Ewing's sarcoma is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after osteosarcoma. Onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is seen on radiology (as shown below) and Homer-Wright rosettes, which are round groupings of cells with a central fibrillary core may be seen histologically.

Option C: Osteoclastoma is also called a giant cell tumour because multinucleated osteoclast-type giant cells are present on histology. The image below shows an X-ray of a giant cell tumor showing an eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis and the typical soap bubble appearance

questions.text: You see a middle-aged man presenting to the psychiatry OPD with the clinical features of speaking to himself, hearing two people talk about him, reduced affect, and impaired judgment which is present for more than 6 months. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has auditory hallucination, reduced affect, lack of insight, impaired judgment for more than 6 months, which makes the diagnosis of schizophrenia more likely.

Diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia (DSM-5):

1. The DSM-5 criteria to diagnose schizophrenia require a total duration of 6 months.

2. Within this 6-month period, there must be at least 1 month of active-phase symptoms (overt psychotic symptoms) where 2 or more of the following have to be present (at least one must be among the a, b, or c): 

  1. Delusion
  2. Hallucination
  3. Disorganized speech (or formal thought disorder)
  4. Disorganized behavior
  5. Affective flattening or other negative symptoms

3. The rest of the 6-month period may include

  • Continuing psychotic symptoms
  • Prodromal symptoms preceding clear-cut psychosis
  • Residual symptoms after the resolution of the psychotic symptoms

4. Residual symptoms are defined as attenuated forms of psychotic symptoms, such as:

  • Odd beliefs
  • Magical thinking
  • Ideas of reference
  • Odd perceptual experiences
  • Peculiar or concrete thinking
  • Vague speech
  • Odd behavior
  • Negative symptoms may also be included

5. Exclusion of mood disorder & substance abuse

Note: DSM-5 does not require that delusions must be bizarre.

Related Pearl: Psychotic disorders

questions.text: A  patient was given halothane for a surgical procedure. After few minutes, the anaesthetist noticed that he developed rigidity and hyperthermia. Which of the following ions is the reason for the above symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of rigidity and hyperthermia with halothane suggests the diagnosis of malignant hyperthermia. The ion responsible for it is calcium.

Malignant hyperthermia is a rare genetic hypermetabolic muscle disease, the characteristic signs, and symptoms of which most commonly appear with exposure to inhaled anesthetics or succinylcholine. 

The pathophysiology behind the development of malignant hyperthermia is that there is an uncontrolled increase in intracellular calcium in skeletal muscle. The sudden release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum removes the inhibition of troponin, resulting in sustained muscle contraction. Markedly increased ATPase activity results in an uncontrolled hypermetabolic state with significantly increased oxygen consumption & CO2 production, producing severe lactic acidosis and hyperthermia. 

Related Pearl: Malignant hyperthermia key features

Pathophysiology:

  • Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

  • Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis
  • Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia
  • Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria
  • Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

  • Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2
  • Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).
  • Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 
  • Cooling the patient

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented with a skin lesion as shown below. Biopsy shows the presence of multiple neutrophilic foci in the stratum corneum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image represents plaque psoriasis. The characteristic histopathological finding in psoriasis consists of multiple neutrophilic foci in the parakeratotic stratum corneum i.e Munro’s microabscesses and spongiform neutrophils in the spinous layer of the epidermis i.e spongiform pustules of Kogoj.

Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin with systemic manifestations. Plaque psoriasis is the most common type. The nails are frequently involved and punctate pitting is the most common finding seen. Psoriasis is associated with Koebner or isomorphic phenomenon. It describes the appearance of new lesions along the site of trauma (linear lesions)

  • The peak on occurrence is between 16 to 22 years and between 57 to 62 years. They usually present with itching and a papulosquamous rash.
  • The lesions are red, scaly, and have well demarcation from the normal skin.
  • They can also be encircled by a clear peripheral zone which is called the Woronoff ring.
  • They commonly appear in the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

Topical application of steroids, retinoids, vitamin D, and emollients is the mainstay of management. Phototherapy and oral methotrexate, acitretin, and cyclosporine can also be used.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

  • I – Irregular pitting pattern

questions.text: 33 yr old female with fever, weight loss, elevated levels of ACE levels presented with chest X-ray as below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with elevated ACE levels and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy is suggestive of sarcoidosis.

Depending on the stage of sarcoidosis radiological features can range from a normal chest radiograph to pulmonary fibrosis.

Stage 0: Normal chest radiograph.

Stage I: Hilar or mediastinal nodal enlargement only.

Stage II: Nodal enlargement and parenchymal disease.

Stage III: Parenchymal disease only.

Stage IV: End-stage lung (pulmonary fibrosis)

questions.text: The dye used for the diagnosis of esophageal perforation:
questions.solution:
Iohexol is the contrast medium used for the diagnostic work up for a suspected case of esophageal perforation instead of barium contrast to prevent barium-related inflammation of the mediastinum.

Note: Although Gastrograffin (water soluble) was used previously, it has high chances of causing aspiration pneumonitis and pulmonary edema consequently. Hence not preferred nowadays.

Contraindications to use of Barium:

  • Tracheo-esophageal fistula: Dianosil-water soluble non-ionic agent is used.
  • Esophageal perforation: Iohexol
  • Perforation peritonitis: Gastrograffin / Iohexol
